Award.AwardTitle: BRIGE: Understanding and Managing Humanitarian Logistics Systems through Advances in Optimization and Game Theory

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Broadening Participation Research Initiation Grant in Engineering (BRIGE) grant provides funding to quantitatively assess the loss of efficiency that occurs in humanitarian and public health logistics systems in the absence of a centralized decision-making authority and to discover mechanisms to mitigate this impact by optimally designing system parameters. Centralized decision-making in such settings is unlikely, but decentralized system outcomes can be poor. This research will examine settings in which individuals choose a facility for service, for example, to pick up needed supplies after a disaster or be vaccinated against an infectious disease. Models will be created by integrating concepts from game theory and optimization to represent decisions of decentralized agents, who act according to different objectives but whose decisions impact overall system outcomes. New theoretical performance bounds will be developed to compare the performance of the decentralized system to a best-case system in which a centralized planner can assign individuals to facilities. Efficient algorithms will be sought to solve the decentralized problem. Finally, mechanisms will be designed to coordinate the decentralized system, or ensure that its performance more closely approximates a centralized one.

If successful, the results of this research will lead to the creation of new optimization and game theory tools with significant potential to inform decision-making in humanitarian and public health logistics systems. The research will highlight opportunities for greater efficiency and effectiveness in these settings, improving the utilization of scarce resources and outcomes for affected populations. Analysis of the proposed models will also advance theoretical understanding of more general decentralized networks. The proposed research activities are integrated with a broadening participation plan that will create pathways to engineering careers for pre-college and undergraduate students from underrepresented groups by engaging these students in outreach and research activities that illustrate ways that engineers make a difference in society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research objective of this Broadening Participation Research Initiation Grant in Engineering (BRIGE) project is to quantitatively assess the loss of efficiency that occurs in humanitarian and public health logistics systems in the absence of a centralized decision-making authority and to discover mechanisms to mitigate this impact by optimally designing system parameters. New knowledge is needed to quantify the impact of decentralization and design systems in ways that account for it. The specific problem setting is one in which individuals choose a facility for service, for example, to receive supplies after a disaster or be vaccinated against an infectious disease. The choice is based on a utility function that incorporates travel time to the facility, waiting time, and the relative importance that the individual places on these parameters. We model this system using optimization and game theory.

 The broadening participation objective of this project is to create pathways that lead to engineering careers for students from underrepresented groups by engaging undergraduate students in humanitarian logistics research and by involving pre-college students in hands-on activities that illustrate ways that engineers make a difference in society.

 

The project has three major goals:

1.  Advance understanding of decentralized humanitarian logistics systems by answering fundamental questions about the complexity of computing decentralized solutions, the quality of those solutions, and the potential to mitigate the inefficiency of decentralization through coordination mechanisms.

2.  Engage undergraduate students from underrepresented groups in research.

3.  Introduce middle and high school students, especially those from underrepresented groups, to humanitarian applications of industrial engineering.

 

The project resulted in the following significant outcomes:

  • We proved that the decentralized system of interest can be arbitrarily inefficient in general.  We also provide multiple bounds on best- and worst-case decentralized system costs as functions of problem parameters. 
  • Our work identified new coordination mechanisms under which the central optimal solution is an equilibrium solution for this class of decentralized systems, as well as an optimization model to identify mechanism values.  Together, these make it possible to create tools for managing decentralized systems to mitigate inefficiencies.
  • An education game, HERO: Humanitarian Engineers Responding Optimally, and accompanying instructional materials was developed for outreach events with middle and high school students to introduce them to humanitarian applications of industrial engineering and provide information about ways they can prepare now to study engineering in the future.
